titleInfo.title: Performance Analysis and Evaluation of Reduced-Precision Computation on the Tendral Statistical Interpolation System (T-Sis) for Ocean Modeling

mods:mods.abstract: This dissertation researches the performance analysis and evaluation of applying reduced-precision computation on the Tendral Statistical Interpolation System (T-SIS) for ocean modeling. It addresses the overarching research question: how to evaluate and test if reduced, numerical precision computation for a domain specific, geophysical scientific data assimilation software can produce comparable results to full-precision. It is a reference for designing and evaluating reduced-precision experiments for a domain specific application to test if the scientific results will still be valid if the software is reengineered to take advantage of the energy-efficient architecture of hardware accelerators. The results of evaluating reduced-precision on T-SIS for ocean modeling Version 1, an optimal interpolation data assimilation (DA) scheme, and Version 2, a unique implementation of a Gaussian Markov Random Fields (GMRF) DA scheme, are presented. The reduced-precision experiments, assimilating a single day of observations, produce similar results for the global domain and the non-uniform, chaotic, ocean currents in the Gulf of Mexico domain compared to the full-precision simulations. The final experiments test the resiliency of running the reduced-precision data assimilation with the HYbrid Coordinate Ocean Model (HYCOM) on a temporal series, multi-year hindcast and using the output to train a Machine Learning (ML) ocean prediction model. The results of the reduced-precision data assimilation and ML experiments show they can produce comparable results to the full-precision for multi-day ocean forecasts with real-world, sparse, noisy observational data. The restart period for the reduced-precision forecast is an important factor for minimizing the divergence of the simulation from the full-precision runs; however the ML training and prediction is not affected by the restart period. The seasonal variation in the observational data also affects the forecast error in both the reduced-precision and ML experiments. In conclusion, the reduced-precision computations in the T-SIS data assimilation for ocean models produces comparable results to the full-precision simulations for both benchmark and operational runs for different model resolutions and assimilating a time-series of variable observational data. Implementing the reduced-precision data assimilation software and using the framework to test and evaluate the science on hardware accelerators will be key to harnessing the performance gains provided by new generation architectures.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Gary Tyson, Professor Directing Dissertation; Linda DeBrunner, University Representative; David Whalley, Committee Member; Xin Yuan, Committee Member.
